facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1064 of 1967

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 1064 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 19, 1966 of the Orissa High Court in Original Jurisdiction Case No. 208 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 19, 1966 of Orissa High Court in Original Jurisdiction Case No. 208 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 19, 1966 of the Orissa High Court in Original Jurisdiction Case No. 208 of 1964. V. Gupte, and B. P. Maheshwari, for the appellant.

facts.text: Writ Petition filed by appellant for quashing order of Government passed on July 14, 1964 informing retirement on January 1, 1965 at age 55

anchor.surface_text: rejecting a Writ Petition filed by the appellant for quashing the order of the Government passed on him on July 14, 1964 informing him that he was to retire from Government service on 1st January, 1965 when he would reach the age of 55 years.

facts.text: Appellant born on January 1, 1910

anchor.surface_text: The facts are shortly as follows. The appellant who was born on January 1, 1910 entered the service of the former Indian State of Mayurbhanj in Orissa as an engineer on 1st November 1937.

facts.text: Appellant entered service of former Indian State of Mayurbhanj as engineer on November 1, 1937

anchor.surface_text: born on January 1, 1910 entered the service of the former Indian State of Mayurbhanj in Orissa as an engineer on 1st November 1937. He was in the employment of that State up to December 31, 1948.

facts.text: Appellant in employment of Mayurbhanj State up to December 31, 1948

anchor.surface_text: as an engineer on 1st November 1937. He was in the employment of that State up to December 31, 1948. On the merger of that State with the Province of Orissa on January 1, 1949 he became an officer of the said Province.

facts.text: Merger of Mayurbhanj State with Province of Orissa on January 1, 1949; appellant became officer of Province

anchor.surface_text: up to December 31, 1948. On the merger of that State with the Province of Orissa on January 1, 1949 he became an officer of the said Province. The age of superannuation of Government employees in Orissa was then 55 years.

facts.text: Age of superannuation of Government employees in Orissa was 55 years

anchor.surface_text: Province. The age of superannuation of Government employees in Orissa was then 55 years. On May 21, 1963 the Government of Orissa passed a resolution the relevant portion whereof ran as follows-

facts.text: Government of Orissa passed resolution on May 21, 1963 raising age of compulsory retirement from 55 to 58 years with effect from December 1, 1962

anchor.surface_text: On May 21, 1963 the Government of Orissa passed a resolution the relevant portion whereof ran as follows- The question of raising the age of companypulsory retirement of the State Government employees has been under the companysideration of Gover nment for some time past. . . . After careful companysideration, Government have number.decided that the age of companypulsory retirement for the State Government employees should be raised from 55 years to 58 years with effect from 1-12-1962.

facts.text: Resolution proviso: appointing authority may require Government servant to retire after age 55 on 3 months notice without reason

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything companytained in the preceding paragraph, the appointing authority may require a Government servant to retire after he attains the age of 55 years on three months previous numberice in writing without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Notification issued by Government of Orissa on February 5, 1964 laying down criteria for retirement rule

anchor.surface_text: On February 5, 1964 a numberification was issued by the Govern- ment of Orissa in companynection with the above laying down the criteria and procedure to be adopted to ensure uniformity of operation of the rule mentioned in paragraph 3 of the above resolution

facts.text: Appellant asked to retire from Government service on January 1, 1965 by order dated July 14, 1964

anchor.surface_text: On July 14, 1964 the appellant was asked to retire from Government service on 1st January, 1965. His representation for reconsideration was number accepted.

facts.text: Appellant's representation for reconsideration not accepted

anchor.surface_text: on 1st January, 1965. His representation for reconsideration was number accepted. He filed a Writ Petition in the High Court on December 21, 1964.

facts.text: Writ Petition filed in High Court on December 21, 1964

anchor.surface_text: was number accepted. He filed a Writ Petition in the High Court on December 21, 1964. This was rejected by the High Court on September 19, 1966.

facts.text: High Court rejected Writ Petition on September 19, 1966

anchor.surface_text: in the High Court on December 21, 1964. This was rejected by the High Court on September 19, 1966. The appellant has companye up by certificate to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant had not completed 30 years qualifying service on January 1, 1965

anchor.surface_text: As there was numberdispute that the appellant had number companypleted 30 years of such service on 1st January .1965 It was urged on behalf of the appellant that Government companyld number resort to paragraph 3 of the said resolution.

facts.text: Before May 21, 1963, employees superannuated at 55 years regardless of 30 years service

anchor.surface_text: Before May 21, 1963 an employee of the Government of Orissa would have been due for superannuation when he attained the age of 55 years whether he had or had number put in thirty years qualifying service.

facts.text: Resolution of May 21, 1963 raised superannuation age to 58 but reserved right to retire at 55

anchor.surface_text: The resolution of May 21, 1963 raised the age of superannuation from 55 to 58 but nevertheless under paragraph 3 thereof the Government reserved to itself a right to ask any employee to retire when he attained the age of 55 years without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant submitted that appellant could not be retired at 55 without 30 years service under resolution para 3

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant raised only two points in support ,of the appeal. His first submission was that as, the, appellant bad number companypleted 30 years service on January 1, 1965 he companyld number be asked. to retire on that date

facts.text: Order of July 14, 1964 did not cast stigma on appellant

anchor.surface_text: On the second point it is enough to point out that the order of July 14, 1964 did number cast any aspersions or stigma on the appellant which would attract Art. 311.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by certificate

anchor.surface_text: by the High Court on September 19, 1966. The appellant has companye up by certificate to this Court.

facts.text: Criteria in notification of Feb 5, 1964 include scrutiny of service record 6 months before 55, integrity, physical/mental condition, performance

anchor.surface_text: Speaking broadly, the idea behind the numberification was that  1  the service record of an officer was to be scrutinised six months before he was due to attain the age of fifty five years,  2  in any case where Government had reasonable cause to believe that he lacked in integrity

facts.text: Government servants could voluntarily retire after 55 with 3 months notice per resolution

anchor.surface_text: The Government servants also may after attaining the age of 55 years, voluntarily retire by giving three months numberice to the appointing authority.
violative of the protection given by Art. III of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Government could invoke paragraph 3 of the May 21, 1963 resolution to require the appellant to retire at age 55 on January 1, 1965, given that he had not completed 30 years qualifying service as per the Liberalised Pension Rules

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant raised only two points in support of the appeal. His first submission was that as, the, appellant bad number companyleted 30 years service on January 1, 1965 he companyld number be asked. to retire on that date

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the criteria laid down by the numberification dated February 5, 1964 the order of retirement dated July 14, 1964 cast a stigma ,on him and as such was violative of the protection given by Art. III of the Constitution. The submission of learned counsel

anchor.surface_text: The resolution of May 21, 1963 raised the age of superannuation from 55 to 58 but nevertheless under paragraph 3 thereof the Government reserved to itself a right to ask any employee to retire when he attained the age of 55 years without assigning any reason. This was. not unilateral.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior to May 21, 1963, superannuation occurred at 55 regardless of qualifying service length; resolution raised age to 58 but para 3 independently preserved right to retire at 55 without reason or link to 30 years service under pension rules

holdings.text: In our view the above contention cannot be accepted

anchor.surface_text: In our view the above contention cannot be accepted. Before May 21, 1963 an employee of the Government of Orissa would have been due for superannuation when he attained the age of 55 years whether he had or had not put in thirty years qualifying service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's construction linking para 3 to 30 years requirement rejected; para 3 additional to existing pension rules and pre-existing superannuation practice

holdings.text: in our view the above observations relied on by counsel do not help the appellant

anchor.surface_text: in our View the above observations relied on by counsel do not help the appellant. The above observations show that a rule which permits a Government to ask an officer to retire after an unreasonably short period of service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gurdev Singh distinguished as it invalidated rule with only 10 years service amounting to removal; inapplicable here where retirement at 55 after substantial service

holdings.text: a rule which permits a Government to ask an officer to retire after an unreasonably short period of service much before the normal age of superannuation would be hit by Art. 311. They cannot apply when the period of qualifying service mentioned in the rule is not unreasonably short and the normal age of superannuation fixed is not unaccountably early

anchor.surface_text: The above observations show that a rule which permits a Government to ask an officer to retire after an unreasonably short period of service much before the normal age of superannuation would be, hit by Art. 311. They cannot apply when the period of qualifying service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compulsory retirement valid exception to Art. 311(2) unless qualifying service unreasonably short (e.g., below 25 years) or superannuation age unaccountably early; follows precedent with rider

holdings.text: The fact that the age of superannuation was raised from 55 to 58 while Government reserved to itself a right to ask any employee to retire at the age of 55 does not violate Art. 311(2)

anchor.surface_text: Before May 1963 a Government servant in Orissa had to retire on attaining the age of 55 years whether he had completed 30 years qualifying service or not. The fact that the age of superannuation was raised from 55 to 58 while Government reserved to itself a right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reservation of pre-existing right to retire at 55 alongside raised superannuation age does not create unreasonable rule violating Art. 311

holdings.text: the order of July 14, 1964 did not cast any aspersions or stigma on the appellant which would attract Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: does not violate Art. 311(2). On the second point it is enough to point out that the order of July 14, 1964 did not cast any aspersions or stigma on the appellant which would attract Art. 311.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order simply invokes para 3 right without reasons or reference to integrity, performance etc.; bare retirement order casts no stigma requiring Art. 311 protections

holdings.text: the fact that by the notification of 5th February 1964 certain guidelines were indicated to the Heads of Departments in considering whether a Government servant should continue in service beyond the age of 55 years, one of the factors for consideration being lack of integrity, did not imply that any officer whose continuance in service was not advised lacked in integrity

anchor.surface_text: Under paragraph 3 of the resolution mentioned Government had a right to require any Government servant to retire at the age of 55 without assigning any reason. The fact that by the notification of 5th February 1964 certain guidelines were indicated to the Heads of Departments

holdings.reasoning_summary: Internal guidelines for discretion do not alter nature of order or imply adverse findings when not stated; no stigma cast

holdings.text: In the result we must hold that there has been no violation of Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case, we cannot say that any evil aspersion was cast on the appellant. In the result we must hold that there has been no violation of Art.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal of both contentions leads to conclusion no constitutional violation in retirement order

precedents.citation: Gurdev Singh Sidhu v. State of Punjab and Another  1

anchor.surface_text: Gurdev Singh Sidhu v. State of Punjab and Another  1 . There this Court struck down article- 91 of the Pepsu Service Regulations under which the Government sought to retain an absolute right to. retire any Government servant after he had companypleted ten years qualifying service without giving any reason.

precedents.case_name: Gurdev Singh Sidhu v. State of Punjab and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: A rule permitting compulsory retirement after unreasonably short period like 10 years amounts to removal under Art. 311(2)
precedents.cited_holding: Struck down article 91 of Pepsu Service Regulations allowing retirement after 10 years qualifying service

precedents.cited_proposition: Rules of compulsory retirement after reasonable qualifying service do not attract Art. 311(2)

precedents.cited_proposition: Majority view that compulsory retirement after substantial service is valid exception to Art. 311(2), with rider on not reducing minimum unreasonably

precedents.citation: Deka etc. v. The General Manager, North East Frontier Railway etc.  1

anchor.surface_text: Deka etc. v. The General Manager, North East Frontier Railway etc.  1  this Court observed by way of explanation that . the majority judgment took the precaution of adding a numbere of caution that if a rule of companypulsory retirement purported to give authority to the Government to terminate the services of a permanent public, servant at a very early stage of his career, the question about the validity of such a rule may have to be examined.

precedents.case_name: Deka v. The General Manager, North East Frontier Railway
precedents.cited_proposition: Compulsory retirement under rules prescribing normal age of superannuation and reasonably long qualifying service does not amount to dismissal or removal under Art. 311(2)
